elements.content: Two novel POM-based inorganic–organic hybrids, [Cu6 II(2,2′-bipy)6(Mo6O22)­(SiW12O40)] n (1), and {[Cu6 II(ppz)6(H2O)5(MoO4)­(SiW12O40)]·4H2O} n (2) (2,2′-bipy = 2,2′-bipyridine, Hppz = 3-(pyrid-2-yl)­pyrazole), have been constructed from heteropolytungstates and molybdates. Two compounds have been identified by single crystal X-ray diffraction, elemental analysis, and FT-IR. Compound 1 shows a 1D (one-dimensional) chain structure constructed from classical Keggin heteropolytungstate [SiW12O40]4– clusters and [Cu6(2,2′-bipy)6] modified isopolymolybdates [Mo6O22]8–. Compound 2 also represents a 1D chain-like motif built from classical Keggin heteropolytungstate [SiW12O40]4– clusters and [Cu8(ppz)6(H2O)5] modified molybdates MoO4 2–. Compound 1 represents the first example of POM-based inorganic–organic hybrid with mixed heteropolytungstates and isopolymolybdates. ESI-MS (electrospray ionization mass spectrometry) technique was employed to reveal the species and their evolutions in the hydrothermal reaction, whereby trivacant [SiW9] building block gradually transforms to classical Keggin [SiW12] during assembly process. Furthermore, the electrocatalytic and magnetic properties were discussed in details.

Compound 2 also represents a 1D chain-like motif built from classical Keggin heteropolytungstate [SiW12O40]4- clusters and [Cu8(ppz)6(H2O)5] modified molybdates MoO4 2-. Furthermore, the electrocatalytic and magnetic properties were discussed in details.

elements.content: Two novel POM-based inorganic−organic hybrids have been constructed from heteropolytungstates and metal−organic module modified molybdates. ESI-MS was used to resolve the species and their evolutions in the hydrothermal reaction. Both of them exhibit excellent electrocatalytic activities to reduce NO2 −.

ESI-MS was used to resolve the species and their evolutions in the hydrothermal reaction. Both of them exhibit excellent electrocatalytic activities to reduce NO2 -.

elements.content: Polyoxometalates (POMs) have permeated most aspects of chemistry and material fields during the past decades not only because of their unmatched structural features including the modulable geometry, dimension, charge state, and oxygen-enriched nucleophilic surface but also various excellent applications in biology, catalysis, medicine, energy, and nanoscience. The exploration of novel POMs and related hybrid compounds are still core prerequisites and permanent mission in POM chemistry field. To date, synthesis effort still focus on the assembly from single type of POMs, such as Keggin-, Dawson-, Anderson-, Waugh-, Silverton-, and Lindquist-type structures. Very seldom efforts have ever been devoted to the mixed POMs (mPOMs) combining more than one type of POMs. The very limited mPOMs are only constituted by two kinds of polymolybdates (including isopolymolybdates and heteropolymolybdates) or isopolymolybdates and isopolyoxovanadates in one structure. The integration of heteropolytungstates and isopolymolybdates into one compound has never been reported hitherto, but should be very promising in both structure and property aspects due to possible synergistic effects from the coexisted multiple W­(VI) and Mo­(VI) centers in one unity. On the one hand, the forms of POM are sensitive to pH values, and a slight pH fluctuation can induce the formation of different POM aggregates. The heterpolytungstates and isopolymolybdates usually exist in different pH range and are difficult to isolate in one compound. On the other hand, heterpolytungstates and isopolymolybdates possess various hydrolytic complexities which also prevent their coexistence in one system. Consequently, the incorporation of two distinct POMs in one structure might be advantageous and is a highly challenging task.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Polyoxometalates (POMs) have permeated most aspects of chemistry and material fields during the past decades not only because of their unmatched structural features including the modulable geometry, dimension, charge state, and oxygen-enriched nucleophilic surface but also various excellent applications in biology, catalysis, medicine, energy, and nanoscience. The exploration of novel POMs and related hybrid compounds are still core prerequisites and permanent mission in POM chemistry field. To date, synthesis effort still focus on the assembly from single type of POMs, such as Keggin-, Dawson-, Anderson-, Waugh-, Silverton-, and Lindquist-type structures. Very seldom efforts have ever been devoted to the mixed POMs (mPOMs) combining more than one type of POMs. The very limited mPOMs are only constituted by two kinds of polymolybdates (including isopolymolybdates and heteropolymolybdates) or isopolymolybdates and isopolyoxovanadates in one structure. The integration of heteropolytungstates and isopolymolybdates into one compound has never been reported hitherto, but should be very promising in both structure and property aspects due to possible synergistic effects from the coexisted multiple W(VI) and Mo(VI) centers in one unity. On the one hand, the forms of POM are sensitive to pH values, and a slight pH fluctuation can induce the formation of different POM aggregates. The heterpolytungstates and isopolymolybdates usually exist in different pH range and are difficult to isolate in one compound. On the other hand, heterpolytungstates and isopolymolybdates possess various hydrolytic complexities which also prevent their coexistence in one system. Consequently, the incorporation of two distinct POMs in one structure might be advantageous and is a highly challenging task.

elements.content: Here, by systematically adjusting the organic ligands, metal salts and pH values, we isolated five POM-based compounds (). Among them, 1 and 2 are the most fascinating and formulated as [Cu6 II(2,2′-bipy)6(Mo6O22)­(SiW12O40)] n (1) and {[Cu6 II(ppz)6(H2O)5(MoO4)­(SiW12O40)]·4H2O} n (2). Compound 1 incorporates mixed heteropolytungstates and isopolymolybdates, whereas compound 2 combines heteropolytungstates and simple molybdates. The remaining three (3–5) were only discussed in Supporting Information (SI). Compound 1 shows a 1D chain structure constructed from classical Keggin heteropolytungstate [SiW12O40]4– clusters and [Cu6(2,2′-bipy)6] modified isopolymolybdates [Mo6O22]8–. While compound 2 is a 1D motif built from classical Keggin heteropolytungstate [SiW12O40]4– clusters and [Cu8(ppz)6(H2O)5] modified molybdates MoO4 2–. To our knowledge, compound 1 is the first example of POM-based inorganic–organic hybrid with mixed heteropolytungstates and isopolymolybdates. Furthermore, the crystal structures, assembly process, electrocatalytic activities, and the magnetic properties have been investigated.

Compound 1 shows a 1D chain structure constructed from classical Keggin heteropolytungstate [SiW12O40]4- clusters and [Cu6(2,2'-bipy)6] modified isopolymolybdates [Mo6O22]8-. While compound 2 is a 1D motif built from classical Keggin heteropolytungstate [SiW12O40]4- clusters and [Cu8(ppz)6(H2O)5] modified molybdates MoO4 2-. To our knowledge, compound 1 is the first example of POM-based inorganic-organic hybrid with mixed heteropolytungstates and isopolymolybdates. elements.clean_text: 1  Synthesis Route for 1-5

elements.content: All chemicals were commercially acquired and employed without further purification. Na10[SiW9O34]·18H2O was obtained according to the previous reported procedue. FT-IR spectra were obtained with a PerkinElmer FT-IR Spectrometer Spectrum Two in the range of 4000–450 cm–1. The C, H, N elemental analyses were determined on a Vario EL III analyzer, whereas the Si, Cu, W, and Mo analyses were performed by a Leaman inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were measured on a Philips X′ Pert Pro MPD X-ray diffractometer (Cu Kα = 1.5418 Å) with an X′ Celerator detector. Magnetic measurements were performed on a SQUID based Quantum Design MPMS 3 magnetometer. Temperature-dependent susceptibilities χ­(T) were measured between 2 and 300 K in magnetic field of 1000 Oe. The electrochemical measurements were performed on a CHI 660E electrochemical workstation (CH Instruments, Shanghai Chenhua Co.) with a conventional three-electrode cell consisting of a Pt plate as the counter electrode. Ag/AgCl (3 M KCl filled) was used as the reference electrode. The working electrode was a carbon paste electrode (CPE). The mass spectra were collected on a ESI-TOF-MS spectrometer Agilent 6224 (Agilent Technologies, USA). The instrument was calibrated with an ESI tuning mix (Agilent) before mass analysis. The sample was introduced by a syringe pump (KDS-100, KD Scientific, Holliston, MA, USA) at a flow rate of 5 μL/min. The nebulizing nitrogen gas pressure was 15 psi, the capillary voltage was 4 kV, the desolvation gas flow rate was 4 L/min, and the desolvation gas temperature was 100 °C around the MS-inlet capillary entrance.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All chemicals were commercially acquired and employed without further purification. Na10[SiW9O34]⋅18H2O was obtained according to the previous reported procedue. FT-IR spectra were obtained with a PerkinElmer FT-IR Spectrometer Spectrum Two in the range of 4000-450 cm-1. The C, H, N elemental analyses were determined on a Vario EL III analyzer, whereas the Si, Cu, W, and Mo analyses were performed by a Leaman inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were measured on a Philips X' Pert Pro MPD X-ray diffractometer (Cu Kα = 1.5418 Å) with an X' Celerator detector. Magnetic measurements were performed on a SQUID based Quantum Design MPMS 3 magnetometer. Temperature-dependent susceptibilities χ(T) were measured between 2 and 300 K in magnetic field of 1000 Oe. The electrochemical measurements were performed on a CHI 660E electrochemical workstation (CH Instruments, Shanghai Chenhua Co.) with a conventional three-electrode cell consisting of a Pt plate as the counter electrode. Ag/AgCl (3 M KCl filled) was used as the reference electrode. The working electrode was a carbon paste electrode (CPE). The mass spectra were collected on a ESI-TOF-MS spectrometer Agilent 6224 (Agilent Technologies, USA). The instrument was calibrated with an ESI tuning mix (Agilent) before mass analysis. The sample was introduced by a syringe pump (KDS-100, KD Scientific, Holliston, MA, USA) at a flow rate of 5 μL/min. The nebulizing nitrogen gas pressure was 15 psi, the capillary voltage was 4 kV, the desolvation gas flow rate was 4 L/min, and the desolvation gas temperature was 100 °C around the MS-inlet capillary entrance.

elements.content: A mixture of Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (48.32 mg, 0.2 mmol), Na10[SiW9O34]·18H2O (73.74 mg, 0.03 mmol), Na2MoO4·2H2O (24.19 mg, 0.1 mmol), and 2,2′-bipy (15.62 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 6 mL H2O, and stirred for 10 min at room temperature. The resulting solution (pH = 5.32) was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 160 °C for 3000 min and then cooled to room temperature over 13 h. The final pH = 5.70 after reaction. The green crystals of 1 were obtained. Yield: 30% based on W. Elemental analysis (%) for 1, C60H48N12Cu6Mo6SiW12O62 (M = 5120.27) Calcd: C, 14.07; N, 3.28; H, 0.94; Si, 0.55; Cu, 7.45; W, 43.09; Mo, 11.24. Found: C, 14.28; N, 3.50; H, 1.15; Si, 0.48; Cu, 7.15; W, 43.22; Mo, 11.88. Selected IR peaks (KBr disk, cm–1): 1600­(w), 1446­(w), 1311­(w), 1248­(w), 1174­(w), 1011­(w), 961­(w), 914­(m), 868­(m), 762(s), 621(s), 515(s), 466­(m).

By adjusting the organic ligands, metal salts and pH values, we isolated five different POM compounds in this work (). First, in the similar pH = 5.32 for 1 and 5.40 for 2, when introducing the same POM Na10[SiW9O34]·18H2O and the bigger chelating ligands 2,2′-bipy and Hppz, the molybdates ([Mo6O22]8– for 1 and [MoO4]2– for 2) were involved to expand the structures of 1 and 2. So we obtained both 1D chains structures for 1 and 2. The 1 is the first example of mPOM constructed by heterpolytungstates and isopolymolybdates in one crystal structure. By using ligand Hppz instead of 2,2′-bipy, the initial pH of 5.40 before reaction was changed to 4.23 after reaction for compound 2. The existence of MoO4 2– in weak acid environment is mainly due to its coordination with surrounding [Cu2(ppz)2] metal–organic entities, which prevent its aggregation to polymolybdates. Second, by adjusting the organic ligand with different size and coordinated mode, we obtained a 0D compound {[Cu4 I(Hpz)8(SiW12O40)]·2H2O} n (3) (Figure S1) incorporating four [CuI(Hpz)2] units coordinated in the exterior. So the size and coordinated mode of the organic ligands can affect the metal valence and further affect the dimensionality of the final products. The in situ transformation from CuII to CuI may due to the synergistic effects for pH value, POM ([SiW12O40]4–) and particular organic N-containing ligands in hydrothermal condition. Third, we changed the metal salts and used Co­(NO3)2·6H2O instead of Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O, another 0D supramolecular compound {[Co2(2,2′-bipy)6(SiW11MoO40)]·8H2O} n (4) was isolated (Figure S2). The reduction of the dimensionality is largely for the configuration of metal atoms and the lack of the linkage molybdates. Although Mo atom was doped into [SiW12O40]4– successfully, it was no condense to independent molybdates as observed in 1 and 2. The CoII atoms were also not bound to the POM by coordination bonds. In detailed, there are two influence factors to isolate different structures of 1 and 4 by mediating moderate reaction condition. One is the configuration of metal atoms including coordination geometries and coordination numbers. In 1, the Cu2+ ions adopt five-coordinated modes and give quadrangular pyramid geometries, while the Co2+ ions in 4 possess six-coordinated modes and form otahedral geometries. The other is the different pH range of reaction solution. In 1, the mixture solution initial pH = 5.32 before reaction and the final pH = 5.70 after reaction, while in 4 the initial pH = 6.44 and the final pH = 6.01. The above two factors lead to different aggregations of POMs and linkage modes of metal atoms to induce different structures of 1 and 4. Finally, when we decrease the pH value to 5.12 by adding 1 M HCl in the synthesis of 1, a 0D cluster compound {[Cu2(2,2′-bipy)4(SiW12O40)]·2H2O} n (5) were generally isolated (Figure S3). In this compound, the lower pH blocks the introduction of molybdates which further block the formation of higher dimensionality. Further lower of pH will lead to a large amount of unknown precipitates in this system. Moreover, POMs 1-4 are the new compounds, and POM 5 is a previously reported compound.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis Discussions

By adjusting the organic ligands, metal salts and pH values, we isolated five different POM compounds in this work (). First, in the similar pH = 5.32 for 1 and 5.40 for 2, when introducing the same POM Na10[SiW9O34]⋅18H2O and the bigger chelating ligands 2,2'-bipy and Hppz, the molybdates ([Mo6O22]8- for 1 and [MoO4]2- for 2) were involved to expand the structures of 1 and 2. So we obtained both 1D chains structures for 1 and 2. The 1 is the first example of mPOM constructed by heterpolytungstates and isopolymolybdates in one crystal structure. By using ligand Hppz instead of 2,2'-bipy, the initial pH of 5.40 before reaction was changed to 4.23 after reaction for compound 2. The existence of MoO4 2- in weak acid environment is mainly due to its coordination with surrounding [Cu2(ppz)2] metal-organic entities, which prevent its aggregation to polymolybdates. Second, by adjusting the organic ligand with different size and coordinated mode, we obtained a 0D compound {[Cu4 I(Hpz)8(SiW12O40)]⋅2H2O} n  (3) (Figure S1) incorporating four [CuI(Hpz)2] units coordinated in the exterior. So the size and coordinated mode of the organic ligands can affect the metal valence and further affect the dimensionality of the final products. The in situ transformation from CuII to CuI may due to the synergistic effects for pH value, POM ([SiW12O40]4-) and particular organic N-containing ligands in hydrothermal condition. Third, we changed the metal salts and used Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O instead of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O, another 0D supramolecular compound {[Co2(2,2'-bipy)6(SiW11MoO40)]⋅8H2O} n  (4) was isolated (Figure S2). The reduction of the dimensionality is largely for the configuration of metal atoms and the lack of the linkage molybdates. Although Mo atom was doped into [SiW12O40]4- successfully, it was no condense to independent molybdates as observed in 1 and 2. The CoII atoms were also not bound to the POM by coordination bonds. In detailed, there are two influence factors to isolate different structures of 1 and 4 by mediating moderate reaction condition. One is the configuration of metal atoms including coordination geometries and coordination numbers. In 1, the Cu2+ ions adopt five-coordinated modes and give quadrangular pyramid geometries, while the Co2+ ions in 4 possess six-coordinated modes and form otahedral geometries. The other is the different pH range of reaction solution. In 1, the mixture solution initial pH = 5.32 before reaction and the final pH = 5.70 after reaction, while in 4 the initial pH = 6.44 and the final pH = 6.01. The above two factors lead to different aggregations of POMs and linkage modes of metal atoms to induce different structures of 1 and 4. Finally, when we decrease the pH value to 5.12 by adding 1 M HCl in the synthesis of 1, a 0D cluster compound {[Cu2(2,2'-bipy)4(SiW12O40)]⋅2H2O} n  (5) were generally isolated (Figure S3). In this compound, the lower pH blocks the introduction of molybdates which further block the formation of higher dimensionality. Further lower of pH will lead to a large amount of unknown precipitates in this system. Moreover, POMs 1-4 are the new compounds, and POM 5 is a previously reported compound.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. One mainly structural feature is that 1 is a 1D chain constructed from classical Keggin-type heteropolytungstate [SiW12O40]4– clusters and [Cu6(2,2′-bipy)6] modified isopolymolybdates [Mo6O22]8– (a and b). The basic structural unit of 1 is shown in a, there is one [SiW12O40]4– Keggin-type heteropolytungstate, one [Mo6O22]8– isopolymolybdate, and six [Cu­(2,2′-bipy)]2+ cations around the [Mo6O22]8– cluster. The classical Keggin-type [SiW12O40]4– is composed of a central 2-fold disordered {SiO4} tetrahedron surrounded by four vertex-sharing trimetallic {W3O18} linked by three edge-sharing {WO6} octahedrons (a).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of 1 

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. One mainly structural feature is that 1 is a 1D chain constructed from classical Keggin-type heteropolytungstate [SiW12O40]4- clusters and [Cu6(2,2'-bipy)6] modified isopolymolybdates [Mo6O22]8- (a and b). The basic structural unit of 1 is shown in a, there is one [SiW12O40]4- Keggin-type heteropolytungstate, one [Mo6O22]8- isopolymolybdate, and six [Cu(2,2'-bipy)]2+ cations around the [Mo6O22]8- cluster. The classical Keggin-type [SiW12O40]4- is composed of a central 2-fold disordered {SiO4} tetrahedron surrounded by four vertex-sharing trimetallic {W3O18} linked by three edge-sharing {WO6} octahedrons (a).

elements.content: It is noteworthy that in the structure of 1, it is the [Cu6(2,2′-bipy)6] modified [Mo6O22]8– moiety that serves as the cation. The isopolymolybdate [Mo6O22]8– contains six {MoO6} octahedrons linked by edge- or corner-sharing oxygen atoms and can be as a variant by removing of two {MoO2} units from saturated β-[Mo8O26]4–. It is a rare member in POMs family, which is different from the traditional Lindqvist-type isopolyanion [Mo6O19]2–. Each Mo atom in Lindqvist-[Mo6O19]2– only has one terminal oxygen atom, while each Mo atom in [Mo6O22]8– has two or three terminal oxygen atoms which can offer more coordinated sites. As a result, the [Mo6O22]8– isopolyanion acts as a multidentate ligand to chelate six Cu atoms by the neighboring terminal oxygen atoms to form a [Cu6Mo6O22]4+ entity. At the same time, each Cu atom also coordinates to one 2,2′-bipy ligand to generate a modified [Cu6(2,2′-bipy)6(Mo6O22)]4+ cation (a). The basic bond lengths and angles are in the normal range of previously reported similar compounds (see table S2, ). As can be seen in b, the Keggin-type [SiW12O40]4– anions and the [Cu6(2,2′-bipy)6(Mo6O22)]4+ cations alternately connect with each other to form a 1D infinitely linear chain. Moreover, the 1D chains interact with each other via π···π stacking (the centroid···centroid distances are 3.84 and 3.67 Å, c) between the pyridine rings to give a 3D supramolecular network (d and e). In previous works, two types of interesting inorganic–organic hybrids, [{(SiW11O39)­Mo3S4(H2O)3(μ-OH)}2]·20H2O and [Mo2V2O9(bpy)6]­[SiW12O40], have been reported based on heteropolytungstates and oligomer molybdates. From the detailed analysis of the structures, we found that the first type is a discreted sandwich cluster by heteropolytungstate {W11O39}8– wrapping oligomer {Mo3S4}4+; the second type is an ionic crystal composed of heteropolytungstate [SiW12O40]4– and Mo/V-oxide-based cationic species. In comparison, the above two types of hybrids cannot be considered as genuine species with concomitant heteropolytungstate and isopolymolybdates in one compound since Lindqvist-type POM is actually the smallest POM in this family.

Each Mo atom in Lindqvist-[Mo6O19]2- only has one terminal oxygen atom, while each Mo atom in [Mo6O22]8- has two or three terminal oxygen atoms which can offer more coordinated sites. At the same time, each Cu atom also coordinates to one 2,2'-bipy ligand to generate a modified [Cu6(2,2'-bipy)6(Mo6O22)]4+ cation (a). The basic bond lengths and angles are in the normal range of previously reported similar compounds (see table S2, ). Moreover, the 1D chains interact with each other via π⋅⋅⋅π stacking (the centroid⋅⋅⋅centroid distances are 3.84 and 3.67 Å, c) between the pyridine rings to give a 3D supramolecular network (d and e). From the detailed analysis of the structures, we found that the first type is a discreted sandwich cluster by heteropolytungstate {W11O39}8- wrapping oligomer {Mo3S4}4+; the second type is an ionic crystal composed of heteropolytungstate [SiW12O40]4- and Mo/V-oxide-based cationic species. elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that compound 2 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ and represents a 1D structural feature built from classical Keggin heteropolytungstate [SiW12O40]4– clusters and [Cu8(ppz)6(H2O)5] modified molybdates MoO4 2– (a and b). The basic structural unit of 2 is shown in a, there is one Keggin-type heteropolytungstate [SiW12O40]4–, one simple molybdate MoO4 2–, and four [Cu2(ppz)2]2+ cations around the MoO4 2– anion. The basic bond lengths and angles fall in the normal range of previously reported similar compounds (see table S2, ). The classical Keggin-type [SiW12O40]4– is the same as that in 1. It acts as a tridentate inorganic ligand to coordinate three binuclear [Cu2(ppz)2] clusters using its three terminal oxygen atoms (a). While the molybdate MoO4 2– also uses its four oxygen atoms to link four binuclear [Cu2(ppz)2] clusters, giving a [Cu8(ppz)6(H2O)5] modified MoO4 2– derivatives (b). The ligand ppz “captures” two Cu atoms by its three chelating nitrogen to form the binuclear [Cu2(ppz)2] cluster. As a result, two MoO4 2– are connected by two binuclear [Cu2(ppz)2] to generate a heterobimetallic {Mo2Cu4} ring. Furthermore, two Keggin-[SiW12O40]4– clusters link six binuclear [Cu2(ppz)2] clusters and further are extended by two MoO4 2– to give another big heterotrimetallic ring (b). These two kinds of rings are alternately connected with each other to form a 1D infinitely linear chain (b). Additionally, the 1D chains interact with their neighbors via π···π stacking interactions (the centroid···centroid distances are 3.895 Å, c) between the pyridine and pyrazole rings of 1D chains to form a 3D supramolecular network (d).

The basic structural unit of 2 is shown in a, there is one Keggin-type heteropolytungstate [SiW12O40]4-, one simple molybdate MoO4 2-, and four [Cu2(ppz)2]2+ cations around the MoO4 2- anion. The basic bond lengths and angles fall in the normal range of previously reported similar compounds (see table S2, ). The classical Keggin-type [SiW12O40]4- is the same as that in 1. It acts as a tridentate inorganic ligand to coordinate three binuclear [Cu2(ppz)2] clusters using its three terminal oxygen atoms (a). While the molybdate MoO4 2- also uses its four oxygen atoms to link four binuclear [Cu2(ppz)2] clusters, giving a [Cu8(ppz)6(H2O)5] modified MoO4 2- derivatives (b). The ligand ppz "captures" two Cu atoms by its three chelating nitrogen to form the binuclear [Cu2(ppz)2] cluster. As a result, two MoO4 2- are connected by two binuclear [Cu2(ppz)2] to generate a heterobimetallic {Mo2Cu4} ring. Furthermore, two Keggin-[SiW12O40]4- clusters link six binuclear [Cu2(ppz)2] clusters and further are extended by two MoO4 2- to give another big heterotrimetallic ring (b). These two kinds of rings are alternately connected with each other to form a 1D infinitely linear chain (b). Additionally, the 1D chains interact with their neighbors via π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions (the centroid⋅⋅⋅centroid distances are 3.895 Å, c) between the pyridine and pyrazole rings of 1D chains to form a 3D supramolecular network (d).

elements.content: Compound 3 and 4 are two byproducts but with new structures in this family. Compound 3 crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group while compound 4 in the monoclinic Cc space group. Both of them are 0D structures composed of metal–organic motifs and POM clusters. Compound 3 is constructed from one classical Keggin-type heteropolytungstate [SiW12O40]4– cluster and four [CuI(Hpz)2] units (Figure S1a). The [SiW12O40]4– is the same as that in 1 and 2 and uses its four terminal oxygen atoms to coordinate four [CuI(Hpz)2] units (Figure S1a). In addition, two Hpz ligands coordinate one CuI ion by one of two N atoms to give a [CuI(Hpz)2] units. As a result, four metal–organic units [CuI(Hpz)2] coordinate one [SiW12O40]4– in the exterior to generate a 0D doubly capped structure. While compound 4 is constructed from one nonclassical Keggin-type Mo-doped heteropolytungstate [SiW11MoO40]4– cluster and two free [Co­(2,2′-bipy)3]2+ units to give a 0D supramolecular structure (Figure S2a). The structure of [SiW11MoO40]4– is similar to the classical Keggin-type heteropolytungstate [SiW12O40]4– except one W atom is substituted by Mo atom. The basic bond lengths and angles of 3 and 4 are in the normal ranges as previously reported similar compounds (see Table S2).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of 3 and 4 

Compound 3 and 4 are two byproducts but with new structures in this family. Compound 3 crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group while compound 4 in the monoclinic Cc space group. Both of them are 0D structures composed of metal-organic motifs and POM clusters. Compound 3 is constructed from one classical Keggin-type heteropolytungstate [SiW12O40]4- cluster and four [CuI(Hpz)2] units (Figure S1a). The [SiW12O40]4- is the same as that in 1 and 2 and uses its four terminal oxygen atoms to coordinate four [CuI(Hpz)2] units (Figure S1a). In addition, two Hpz ligands coordinate one CuI ion by one of two N atoms to give a [CuI(Hpz)2] units. As a result, four metal-organic units [CuI(Hpz)2] coordinate one [SiW12O40]4- in the exterior to generate a 0D doubly capped structure. While compound 4 is constructed from one nonclassical Keggin-type Mo-doped heteropolytungstate [SiW11MoO40]4- cluster and two free [Co(2,2'-bipy)3]2+ units to give a 0D supramolecular structure (Figure S2a). The structure of [SiW11MoO40]4- is similar to the classical Keggin-type heteropolytungstate [SiW12O40]4- except one W atom is substituted by Mo atom. The basic bond lengths and angles of 3 and 4 are in the normal ranges as previously reported similar compounds (see Table S2).

elements.content: We also used the electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) to reveal some intermediate species and their evolution in the hydrothermal assembly of 2. The analyte is the solution after hydrothermal reaction. As shown in , there are successive envelops corresponding to [SiW9-Cu], [SiW10-Cu] and [SiW11-Cu] species in the m/z range of 1000–2000, whose charged state are all −2. No recognizable signals of [SiW12-Cu] species were directly observed in solution. We assigned four most dominated envelops (2a–2d) centered at m/z = 1370.5286, 1401.5160, 1415.0439, and 1444.0154 to [Na2Cu4SiW9O34(NO3)2(H2O)5]2–, [Cu4SiW10O37(H2O)5]2–, [Cu4HSiW10O37(NO3)­(H2O)3]2–, and [NaCu4SiW10O37(NO3)­(H2O)5]2–, respectively. The assignments for all main species (2a–2s) in solution are shown in Figure S9 and Table S1 incorporating the experimental and simulated isotope distributions. The [SiW10-Cu] and [SiW11-Cu] peaks appeared rather rhythmic sequence, that is, the separation between peaks from left to right is very similar to Δm/z = 13.5, 14.0, 14.5, or 15.0 that implies the species have approximately same compositions but with coordinative exchanges such as between two waters and one HNO3 (Δm/z = 13.5). These observations are consistent with the final X-ray results, that is, [SiW12–Cu] species are first precipitated as crystals from the solution after reaction, thus almost no signals corresponding to them are found. The rich lacunary POMs species in solution detected by ESI-MS indicated the [SiW12] building block in 2 is generated from the addition of W atom one by one on raw reactant [SiW9] in solution.

We also used the electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) to reveal some intermediate species and their evolution in the hydrothermal assembly of 2. The analyte is the solution after hydrothermal reaction. As shown in , there are successive envelops corresponding to [SiW9-Cu], [SiW10-Cu] and [SiW11-Cu] species in the m/z range of 1000-2000, whose charged state are all -2. No recognizable signals of [SiW12-Cu] species were directly observed in solution. We assigned four most dominated envelops (2a-2d) centered at m/z = 1370.5286, 1401.5160, 1415.0439, and 1444.0154 to [Na2Cu4SiW9O34(NO3)2(H2O)5]2-, [Cu4SiW10O37(H2O)5]2-, [Cu4HSiW10O37(NO3)(H2O)3]2-, and [NaCu4SiW10O37(NO3)(H2O)5]2-, respectively. The assignments for all main species (2a-2s) in solution are shown in Figure S9 and Table S1 incorporating the experimental and simulated isotope distributions. The [SiW10-Cu] and [SiW11-Cu] peaks appeared rather rhythmic sequence, that is, the separation between peaks from left to right is very similar to Δm/z = 13.5, 14.0, 14.5, or 15.0 that implies the species have approximately same compositions but with coordinative exchanges such as between two waters and one HNO3 (Δm/z = 13.5). These observations are consistent with the final X-ray results, that is, [SiW12-Cu] species are first precipitated as crystals from the solution after reaction, thus almost no signals corresponding to them are found. The rich lacunary POMs species in solution detected by ESI-MS indicated the [SiW12] building block in 2 is generated from the addition of W atom one by one on raw reactant [SiW9] in solution.

elements.content: The electrochemical behavior of the compounds 1 and 2 were checked in 1 mol·L–1 H2SO4 aqueous solutions through cyclic voltammetry (CV) with carbon paste electrode (CPE) as a working electrode, and the potential range is −0.6 to 1.0 V. As shown in a and b, the CV of 1-CPE and 2-CPE are all constituted by two pairs of reversible redox peaks and one irreversible oxidation peak in the potential range from 0.1 to 1.0 V (these peaks are more easily detected in differential pulse voltammetry (DPV) (see Figure S10). And their peak potentials locate at 0.602/0.431 V (I–I′), 0.338/0.198 V (II–II′), 0.175 V (III) for 1-CPE, and 0.596/0.465 V (I–I′), 0.463/0.246 V (II–II′), and 0.288 V (III) for 2-CPE (scan rate = 300 mV s–1), respectively, which are attributed to the redox processes of Mo­(VI). Besides, the potentials of the redox peaks IV/IV′ at 0.076/-0.107 V for 1-CPE and 0.151/0.045 V for 2-CPE are ascribed to the redox process of Cu­(II) centers, which can be confirmed by the characteristic redox potentials of those reported Cu­(II) compounds. The reduction of W­(VI) centers of 1-CPE and 2-CPE are expected to occur in the negative potential domain, as can be seen from a and b, 1-CPE has two pairs of invertible redox peaks with potentials situated at −0.223/–0.354 V (V–V′), and −0.425/–0.475 V (VI–VI′), while 2-CPE has two pairs of invertible redox peaks and one irreversible oxidation peak with potentials at −0.248/–0.356 V (V–V′), −0.340/–0.443 V (VI–VI′), and −0.448 V (VII) in the potential range of 0 to −0.6 V. Obviously, they are attributed to the redox process of W­(VI) centers. And the graph we plotted with the square root of the scan rate (v 1/2) as pivot X and the cathodic current (I pc) as pivot Y is a straight line, which shows that the relation between v 1/2 and I pc is a positive correlation, this result indicates the electrochemical process is a diffusion-controlled.

Electrochemical Properties and Electrocatalytic Activities

The electrochemical behavior of the compounds 1 and 2 were checked in 1 mol⋅L-1 H2SO4 aqueous solutions through cyclic voltammetry (CV) with carbon paste electrode (CPE) as a working electrode, and the potential range is -0.6 to 1.0 V. As shown in a and b, the CV of 1-CPE and 2-CPE are all constituted by two pairs of reversible redox peaks and one irreversible oxidation peak in the potential range from 0.1 to 1.0 V (these peaks are more easily detected in differential pulse voltammetry (DPV) (see Figure S10). And their peak potentials locate at 0.602/0.431 V (I-I'), 0.338/0.198 V (II-II'), 0.175 V (III) for 1-CPE, and 0.596/0.465 V (I-I'), 0.463/0.246 V (II-II'), and 0.288 V (III) for 2-CPE (scan rate = 300 mV s-1), respectively, which are attributed to the redox processes of Mo(VI). Besides, the potentials of the redox peaks IV/IV' at 0.076/-0.107 V for 1-CPE and 0.151/0.045 V for 2-CPE are ascribed to the redox process of Cu(II) centers, which can be confirmed by the characteristic redox potentials of those reported Cu(II) compounds. The reduction of W(VI) centers of 1-CPE and 2-CPE are expected to occur in the negative potential domain, as can be seen from a and b, 1-CPE has two pairs of invertible redox peaks with potentials situated at -0.223/-0.354 V (V-V'), and -0.425/-0.475 V (VI-VI'), while 2-CPE has two pairs of invertible redox peaks and one irreversible oxidation peak with potentials at -0.248/-0.356 V (V-V'), -0.340/-0.443 V (VI-VI'), and -0.448 V (VII) in the potential range of 0 to -0.6 V. Obviously, they are attributed to the redox process of W(VI) centers. And the graph we plotted with the square root of the scan rate (v 1/2) as pivot X and the cathodic current (I pc) as pivot Y is a straight line, which shows that the relation between v 1/2 and I pc is a positive correlation, this result indicates the electrochemical process is a diffusion-controlled.

elements.content: The determination and elimination of nitrite ions in environmental and food samples has been paid considerable attention in recent years because of their distinct toxicity and carcinogenicity. As we know, POMs can serve as powerful electron reservoirs for multielectron delivery and reduction which can bestow them as one suitable catalyst candidate. So we investigated the electrocatalytic activities of 1-CPE and 2-CPE toward the reduction of nitrite in 1 mol·L–1 H2SO4 aqueous solutions with the scan rate at 100 mV·s–1. As shown in c and d, both 1-CPE and 2-CPE display good electrocatalytic activities on the reduction of nitrite. With the increased concentration of NO2 –, we observed various degree increments of the cathodic currents in the potential range of −0.6–0.4 V. The increments of the cathodic currents in the potential domain of the redox process for W­(VI) (−0.2 to −0.6 V) are larger than Cu­(II) (0.1 to −0.1 V), and the least is Mo­(VI) (0.2 to 0.4 V). So the electrocatalytic capacities are also in this order: W­(VI) > Cu­(II) > Mo­(VI). In addition, based on the reduction peak currents at −0.6 V, the catalytic efficiencies (CAT) are calculated using the CAT formula. Both 1-CPE and 2-CPE show high CAT values from 237% to 1715% and 161% to 1501% with the increased density of NO2 – from 5 to 25 mmol·L–1, respectively (Figure S13). This also indicates clearly the reduction of NO2 – for 1-CPE is faster than 2-CPE. The reason may be the synergistic strengthening effect of multiple Mo atoms in 1-CPE than 2-CPE for their retaining electrocatalytic properties. We also checked the electrocatalytically reduction of nitrite by 3–5 in the similar condition (Figures S12 and S13), however, they showed low electrocatalytic activities compared to those of 1 and 2.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of compounds 2, 4, and 5 were investigated in 2–300 K temperature range in a magnetic field of 1 kOe. Magnetic measurements have been carried out on crystalline samples of them. According to the obtained data, antiferromagnetic coupling between Cu­(II) ions in 2 can be suggested, as discussed in more detail below. The structure of the compound reveals three pairs of Cu­(II) ions suggesting dimeric behavior of the system. The temperature dependence of the susceptibility of 2 is shown in the inset of . There is a broad peak in the susceptibility at 180 K which is typical for Cu­(II) dimers. Below approximately 50 K the susceptibility increases which is probably due to a small amount of uncoupled Cu­(II) ions in 2. The Cu­(II) ions in the dimers are antiferomagnetically coupled. At low temperatures their magnetic moments cancel out and what is left is a purely paramagnetic contribution of uncoupled Cu­(II) ions, which can be seen as a constant χM T versus T curve in .
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

The magnetic properties of compounds 2, 4, and 5 were investigated in 2-300 K temperature range in a magnetic field of 1 kOe. Magnetic measurements have been carried out on crystalline samples of them. According to the obtained data, antiferromagnetic coupling between Cu(II) ions in 2 can be suggested, as discussed in more detail below. The structure of the compound reveals three pairs of Cu(II) ions suggesting dimeric behavior of the system. The temperature dependence of the susceptibility of 2 is shown in the inset of . There is a broad peak in the susceptibility at 180 K which is typical for Cu(II) dimers. Below approximately 50 K the susceptibility increases which is probably due to a small amount of uncoupled Cu(II) ions in 2. The Cu(II) ions in the dimers are antiferomagnetically coupled. At low temperatures their magnetic moments cancel out and what is left is a purely paramagnetic contribution of uncoupled Cu(II) ions, which can be seen as a constant χM T versus T curve in .

elements.content: Temperature dependence of χM T vs T and χM vs T (inset) for 2 measured in a magnetic field of 1000 Oe. The full lines represent best-fit lines obtained by the Bleaney–Bowers model for dinuclear Cu­(II) compounds.
elements.clean_text: 5  Temperature dependence of χM T vs T and χM vs T (inset) for 2 measured in a magnetic field of 1000 Oe. The full lines represent best-fit lines obtained by the Bleaney-Bowers model for dinuclear Cu(II) compounds.

elements.content: The measured susceptibility data was fitted with the Bleaney–Bowers model for dinuclear Cu­(II) compounds χ = 2 N A μ B g 2 k B T [ 3 + exp ( − 2 J k B T ) ] ( 1 − ρ ) + N A μ B g 2 2 k B T ρ where k B is the Boltzmann constant and ρ is the fraction of uncoupled Cu­(II) ions. The fitting yielded J = −228 cm–1, g = 2.05, and ρ = 0.059. The best-fit lines are shown in and are in good agreement with the measured data.

elements.content: Because of large Co–Co distances (8.2 Å or more) in compound 4 no strong interactions between Co­(II) ions were expected. The temperature dependence of the susceptibility can be described as Curie-like (). The temperature dependence of the effective magnetic moment p eff = 8 χ T shown in the inset of suggests weak interactions between Co­(II) ions. A broad peak centered around 150 K suggest an interplay of ferro- and antiferromagnetic interactions. The sudden increase at 26 K suggests stronger ferromagnetic coupling between Co­(II) ions below that temperature. Above 26 K the values of the effective magnetic moment range from 3.4 to 3.7 μB which in below the expected value (4.8 μB) for isolate Co­(II) ions.17

elements.content: The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility of compound 5 () suggests a Curie behavior described by χ = C/T, where C is the Curie constant. The graph p eff (T) shown in the inset of reveals an almost constant effective magnetic moment of 1.9 μB in the whole temperature interval. The value of p eff is in excellent agreement with the literature value (1.9 μB) for isolated Cu­(II) ions. Thus, the Cu­(II) ions in compound 5 show purely paramagnetic behavior with the expected effective magnetic moment and do not magnetically interact with each other.

elements.content: In conclusion, two novel POM-based inorganic–organic hybrids based on mixed heteropolytungstates and metal–organic modified molybdates have been synthesized and characterized. Both compounds show 1D chain structures constructed from classical Keggin heteropolytungstate [SiW12O40]4– clusters and {CuII-ligands} modified molybdates. ESI-MS was used to reveal the evolutions of raw trivacant [SiW9] building block in the hydrothermal reaction toward the final formation of classical Keggin [SiW12] linker. They also show excellent electrocatalytic abilities to reduce NO2 –. Moreover, the magnetic behaviors of 2, 4, and 5 are also revealed. The preparation of the two compounds may indicate new perspectives for the construction of novel POM-based inorganic–organic hybrids from mixed POMs by carefully selecting appropriate reaction condition.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, two novel POM-based inorganic-organic hybrids based on mixed heteropolytungstates and metal-organic modified molybdates have been synthesized and characterized. Both compounds show 1D chain structures constructed from classical Keggin heteropolytungstate [SiW12O40]4- clusters and {CuII-ligands} modified molybdates. ESI-MS was used to reveal the evolutions of raw trivacant [SiW9] building block in the hydrothermal reaction toward the final formation of classical Keggin [SiW12] linker. They also show excellent electrocatalytic abilities to reduce NO2 -. Moreover, the magnetic behaviors of 2, 4, and 5 are also revealed. The preparation of the two compounds may indicate new perspectives for the construction of novel POM-based inorganic-organic hybrids from mixed POMs by carefully selecting appropriate reaction condition.

A mixture of Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (48.32 mg, 0.2 mmol), Na10[SiW9O34]·18H2O (73.74 mg, 0.03 mmol), Na2MoO4·2H2O (24.19 mg, 0.1 mmol), and 2,2′-bipy (15.62 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 6 mL H2O, and stirred for 10 min at room temperature. The resulting solution (pH = 5.32) was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 160 °C for 3000 min and then cooled to room temperature over 13 h. The final pH = 5.70 after reaction. The green crystals of 1 were obtained. Yield: 30% based on W. Elemental analysis (%) for 1, C60H48N12Cu6Mo6SiW12O62 (M = 5120.27) Calcd: C, 14.07; N, 3.28; H, 0.94; Si, 0.55; Cu, 7.45; W, 43.09; Mo, 11.24. Found: C, 14.28; N, 3.50; H, 1.15; Si, 0.48; Cu, 7.15; W, 43.22; Mo, 11.88. Selected IR peaks (KBr disk, cm–1): 1600­(w), 1446­(w), 1311­(w), 1248­(w), 1174­(w), 1011­(w), 961­(w), 914­(m), 868­(m), 762(s), 621(s), 515(s), 466­(m).

Synthesis of [Cu6 II(2,2'-bipy)6(Mo6O22)(SiW12O40)] n  (1)

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (48.32 mg, 0.2 mmol), Na10[SiW9O34]⋅18H2O (73.74 mg, 0.03 mmol), Na2MoO4⋅2H2O (24.19 mg, 0.1 mmol), and 2,2'-bipy (15.62 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 6 mL H2O, and stirred for 10 min at room temperature. The resulting solution (pH = 5.32) was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 160 °C for 3000 min and then cooled to room temperature over 13 h. The final pH = 5.70 after reaction. The green crystals of 1 were obtained. Yield: 30% based on W. Elemental analysis (%) for 1, C60H48N12Cu6Mo6SiW12O62 (M = 5120.27) Calcd: C, 14.07; N, 3.28; H, 0.94; Si, 0.55; Cu, 7.45; W, 43.09; Mo, 11.24. Found: C, 14.28; N, 3.50; H, 1.15; Si, 0.48; Cu, 7.15; W, 43.22; Mo, 11.88. Selected IR peaks (KBr disk, cm-1): 1600(w), 1446(w), 1311(w), 1248(w), 1174(w), 1011(w), 961(w), 914(m), 868(m), 762(s), 621(s), 515(s), 466(m).

Synthesis of {[Cu6 II(ppz)6(H2O)5(MoO4)(SiW12O40)]⋅4H2O} n  (2)

The synthesis of 2 was similar to that of 1, but Hppz (14.52 mg, 0.1 mmol) instead of 2,2'-bipy. The initial and final pH values of the solution are 5.40 and 4.23 before and after reaction, respectively. The black green crystals of 2 were obtained. Yield: 45% based on W. Elemental analysis (%) for 2, C48H54N18Cu6MoSiW12O53 (M = 4442.41) Calcd: C, 12.98; N, 5.67; H, 1.23; Si, 0.63; Cu, 8.58; W, 49.66; Mo, 2.16. Found: C, 13.05; N, 5.42; H, 1.62; Si, 0.75; Cu, 8.93; W, 50.01; Mo, 2.61. Synthesis of {[Cu4 I(Hpz)8(SiW12O40)]⋅2H2O} n  (3)

The synthesis of 3 was similar to that of 1, but pyrazole (Hpz, 6.81 mg, 0.1 mmol) was instead of 2,2'-bipy. The initial and final pH values of the solution are 5.19 and 4.59 before and after reaction, respectively. The dark crystals were isolated (yield 32% based on W). Synthesis of {[Co2 II(2,2'-bipy)6(SiW11MoO40)]⋅8H2O} n  (4)

The synthesis of 4 was similar to that of 1, but Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (58.20 mg, 0.2 mmol) was instead of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O.
